Since the EU and the US economies account for roughly half of world output and world trade, the scope and international impact of TTIP is considerable. The relatively large integration of both blocs has been the result of the post-war trade liberalisation process, which also included a significant increase in transatlantic investments—both blocs are also each other’s most important investment partners.Footnote 3 This trade liberalisation process, however, has been mostly driven by the reduction of tariff rates. With relatively low tariffs levels at present, the economic focus of TTIP has shifted to the reduction of the biggest remaining hurdles in transatlantic trade: non-tariff barriers (NTBs). Thus, a comprehensive agreement that includes NTBs is expected to provide the most economic impact. Much of the general debate on TTIP, however, has focused on the desirability of regulatory convergence and other political topics.Footnote 4 Although these issues are central to the negotiations on TTIP, and the political aftermath of the negotiations, in this paper we focus our analysis exclusively on the expected economic effects of the agreement. The main objective of this paper, therefore, is to analyse the potential economic effects of TTIP for the Netherlands. To achieve this goal we start by a short description of the main economic elements being negotiated under TTIP and their potential economic effects. We then summarise the main studies that have estimated the economic effects of TTIP. However, these previous TTIP studies have focused on the overall gains for the EU and some of the larger EU countries.Footnote 5 Therefore, in this study we use WorldScan—the CPB in-house computational general equilibrium (CGE) model—to assess the potential economic effects of TTIP for the Netherlands. As part of the TTIP simulations, we have two main policy shocks: elimination of tariffs between the US and all EU countries and reduction in NTB costs. For the second shock, we follow the recent methodological approach in Egger et al. (2015) to estimate the expected NTB reductions associated from TTIP. In our “full” TTIP simulation we combine the previous two policy shocks to have both the tariff elimination and the NTB cost reductions. We find macroeconomic effects for the US and for the aggregated EU region that are similar to the comparable CGE study by Egger et al. (2015).Footnote 6 For the Netherlands, we find that GDP and consumption per capita increase by the year 2030 by more than the EU average, by 1.7 and 3.1% respectively.Footnote 7 This GDP increase is driven by a strong surge of bilateral trade between the US and the EU, which is expected to double: EU exports to the US increase by 111%, while US exports to the EU raise by 119%. Dutch exports to the US increase by 95%, but total exports (to all destinations) increase by a more moderate 4%. TTIP also creates, therefore, strong trade diversion patterns and Dutch exports to other EU countries decreases by 2% and to third regions by roughly 3%. These trade diversion effects also result in a relatively small decrease in trade and GDP for non-TTIP regions. With respect to the labour market, our simulations show that with a full TTIP scenario that eliminates tariffs and reduces NTBs, Dutch average wages will increase by more than 2%. More importantly, the wages of both low- and high-skill workers are expected to rise. This implies that TTIP will not significantly affect wage nor income inequality. The sectoral reorganisation of production, however, implies that workers in declining sectors will need to relocate to other sectors. This labour displacement will have short term adjustment costs for those workers that need to change employment. However, these additional costs are relatively small, since only a small proportion of workers would have to change jobs and move from one sector to another, in comparison to the job creation and destruction that occurs on a yearly basis. In particular, we expect that about 1.5% of total jobs (around 114,000 jobs) will be reallocated to other sectors in a 13 year period, while on a yearly basis, 13% of total jobs (around one million jobs) are either created or destroyed in the Netherlands (Brull et al. 2010).Footnote 8
 Finally, it is important to mention that these potential effects are likely to underestimate the full economic effects of TTIP, since our methodology does not analyse additional economic effects of TTIP related to public procurement provisions, increased FDI and dynamic effects from trade. This paper proceeds as follows. We first explain in Sect. 2 the main characteristics of TTIP and we list the potential economic effects. In Sect. 3 we summarise the main results and the methodological differences between the economic studies that have analysed TTIP. We then explain in Sect. 4 the WorldScan CGE model, how the TTIP experiment is modelled and what are the main economic results for the Netherlands. In Sect. 5 we discuss some additional economic effects related to TTIP and we conclude in Sect. 6.

Title: Bailout Clauses and the Price of Credit: The Dutch Experience for Housing Corporations
Intro: The Dutch (semi-)public sector is well-known for its explicit bailout clauses (or guarantees). The presence of a bailout clause means that if an organisation would run into trouble, it will receive financial assistance from its counterparts or from the government. The idea behind this is to communicate to creditors that providing capital entails no risk. This should reduce interest rates on loans so that more resources can be devoted to the public goal. A major advantage of a guarantee (in contrast to for example a subsidy) is that it does not have to cost society any money if it proves to be sustainable. In many countries, however, bailouts are explicitly ruled out by legislation. This is to prevent ‘moral hazard’; the danger that debtors become less rigorous in controlling their finances knowing that they would be assisted should problems arise (Rodden 2006). Debtors thus face a ‘soft budget constraint’ (Kornai et al. 2003), which is seen to encourage them to behave irresponsibly. Thus in the literature, the dominant view is that an explicit no-bailout clause must be formulated in order to emphatically state to institutions that they will not be rescued (Allers 2015). In practice, however, it is difficult to credibly enforce such a clause. Actual bankruptcy of subnational governments or (semi-)public organisations could entail high welfare and political costs (Goodspeed 2002; Plekhanov and Singh 2007). Indeed, there are numerous examples of bailouts actually occurring despite the existence of a no-bailout clause (Rodden 2006; Heppke-Falk and Wolff 2008). However, in the Dutch public sector explicit and regulated guarantees exist for, e.g., housing corporations, health care institutions and municipalities. In the case of municipalities, Allers (2015) notes that the bailout clause has not led to excessive malpractice. Therefore, he argues, there is sufficient reason to challenge the traditional view that bailouts must be ruled out. It may even be the case that the benefits of a bailout clause (reduced interest payments) outweigh the costs (defaults on loans and/or increased inefficiencies). This paper attempts to measure the effect of a bailout clause on interest rates by focusing on loans made to (housing) corporations. Firstly, by comparing a set of guaranteed and unguaranteed corporation loans, we investigate whether the bailout clause succeeds in lowering interest rates. Secondly, we study whether differences in interest rates can be explained by corporation characteristics such as indebtedness; under a credible bailout clause all corporations should pay the same interest rate on similar loans, regardless of their financial position. Thirdly, we investigate whether the design of the bailout clause is relevant for interest payments by comparing the guarantee system of corporations (which secures individual loans) with that of municipalities (whose entire financial position is secured). Existing literature mostly focuses on no-bailout or implicit bailout clauses (for an overview, see van Hecke et al. 2012). To our knowledge, this paper is the first study investigating the effect of an explicit bailout clause. We exploit a unique micro-level dataset of loans made to housing corporations that distinguishes both guaranteed and unguaranteed loans. This enables us to investigate whether structural differences exist between the two groups of loans. The rest of this paper is set up as follows. Section 2 describes the institutional background of housing corporations, paying special attention to the bailout agreements. Section 3 briefly outlines the theory on interest rate determination and provides hypotheses. In Sect. 4 we present the research set-up and in Sect. 5 the data. Section 6 delivers our main results. The robustness of our findings is tested in a sensitivity analysis presented in Sect. 7. Section 8 offers our conclusions.

Title: Gender Differences in Financial Education: Evidence from Primary School
Consumption Behavior, Annuity Income and Mortality Risk of Retirees
CEOs and CFOs on IPOs: The Process and Success of Going Public
Intro: An initial public offering (IPO) is generally seen as a major event in a firm’s development. Traditionally, empirical research into IPOs has largely focused on the underpricing and aftermarket performance of the shares (Jenkinson and Ljungqvist 2001; Ritter and Welch 2002; Ritter 2003a). More recently, there has been an increasing interest in subjects related to the process and decisions that precede the first day of listing, such as the motives for going public (Pagano et al. 1998; Kim and Weisbach 2008), selecting an underwriter (Schenone 2004; Fernando et al. 2005), syndicate formation (Corwin and Schulz 2005; Cooney et al. 2015), and the price-setting process (Lowry and William Schwert 2004; Lowry et al. 2010). This branch of IPO research mostly employs firm characteristics and market conditions as proxies for the forces that are believed to drive these aspects. Disadvantages of such a method are the indirectness and limited scope due to data constraints. The present study takes an alternative approach to provide insights into the process of going public: we employ interviews with CEOs and CFOs who were closely involved in an IPO, and ask these executives about their views on key aspects of the IPO process and why and how various decisions were made. Our questions among other things relate to the lead manager choice and syndicate formation, the pricing process, the allocation of shares, and the roles of private equity and venture capital. Also, we ask the CEOs and CFOs for their sentiment—in retrospect—towards the success of the IPO and we examine the factors driving their evaluation. With our interviews we complement an excellent but relatively small body of related survey studies. Baker and Johnson (1990) use a questionnaire to examine managerial motives for listing and not listing in the US. Ravasi and Marchisio (2003) investigate the implications of going public, using seven case studies with personal interviews and a questionnaire that was distributed among companies that went public in Italy. The British studies by Burton et al. (2004, 2006) use a questionnaire supplemented by ten interviews with managers and advisors; their first study focuses on corporate governance changes, whereas the second is more general, with an emphasis on the advantages and disadvantages of going public. von Eije et al. (2004) study IPO-related organizational changes; in an interview-like setting they had managers of 27 Dutch companies that went public in the Netherlands or abroad in the period 1987–1997 fill in a questionnaire. Brau et al. (2006), Brau and Fawcett (2006a) and Bancel and Mittoo (2009) use questionnaires among CFOs—from the US, the US and Europe, respectively—to compare managerial motivations for conducting an IPO with academic theories on why firms go public. Brau and Fawcett (2006a) in addition consider underwriter selection, underpricing and signaling—areas that are also examined in the present paper (see also Brau and Fawcett 2006b). Our work differs markedly from these studies in terms of both scope and method. First, we examine a large variety of managerial aspects of the IPO process, whereas the emphasis of earlier studies is on the decision and implications of going public. To the best of our knowledge, most of the issues that we address have not been covered by previous CEO/CFO surveys. Our study is also the first to systematically examine managerial views on the determinants of IPO success. Second, we use in-person, one-to-one interviews, whereas the previous studies are primarily based on mail questionnaires. Our interviews were semi-structured through a uniform set of questions, with the flexibility to discuss interesting responses in more detail. Many questions were open-ended to leave room for unanticipated views and experiences. Important advantages of this approach are in the quality and completeness of the collected information. Furthermore, unlike mail questionnaires, the personal interviews enable us to guarantee that respondents were truly key executives who had been closely involved in the IPO process. A downside of in-person interviews is that they put a limit to the potential scale and geographical scope. We focus on all IPOs that took place in the period 1990–2008 in the Netherlands. In total we conducted 46 interviews, for a response rate of 57%. This relatively high rate is probably the result of the personal nature of both the interview itself and our request to participate. Most interviewees were the CEO at the time of the IPO, and for convenience and brevity we henceforth refer to them as “CEOs”. Our main results can be summarized as follows. The average IPO process lasts 6–7 months. Lead managers are primarily selected because of relational and expertise-related aspects, while analyst coverage, fees and valuation indications are relatively unimportant. Issuing firms’ preferences for the other syndicate members are especially driven by characteristics of the investor client base and by established business relationships. Most CEOs were aware of potential conflicts of interest between the issuing firm and the lead manager, and they actively negotiated about the offer price; at the same time many of them also acknowledge that they did not strive for the highest possible price because of the interest they had in satisfying new shareholders. The interviews provide some evidence of strategic underpricing in anticipation of subsequent equity issues. Pre-marketing feedback is figuring prominently throughout the pricing process. The width of the price range of book-built IPOs is primarily driven by uncertainty about the value of the shares. IPOs are rarely priced above the upper bound of the price range, but about half of the interviewees think that the lead manager would have been prepared to do so. Issuing firms play an active but subordinate role in the allocation of shares, and many CEOs believe that the lead manager’s business interests have had a strong influence on the allocation strategy. CEOs are positive about the overall success of the IPO from the perspective of the firm. The key factors driving their evaluation are how well the firm fared in terms of stock price performance, changes in media attention and visibility, and changes related to the retention and recruitment of staff. These factors are mentioned by the CEOs themselves when we directly ask for the critical success factors, and the same factors also emerge more indirectly when we first ask the CEOs to evaluate a list of pre-specified factors and then regress their overall success ratings on the ratings for these factors. The remainder of the paper is organized as follows. Section 2 describes our survey design and the sample. Section 3 presents the results related to the IPO process, subdivided into duration and organization, lead manager choice and syndicate formation, pricing, allocation, and private equity and venture capital. Section 4 presents our results on the evaluation of IPO success. Section 5 summarizes and concludes.

Title: Tax Bunching by Owners of Small Corporations
Intro:
The taxable income of self-employed individuals is commonly found to respond more strongly to changes in marginal tax rates than the taxable income of wage earners (see e.g. Saez (2010) and Chetty et al. (2011)). The self-employed are better able to avoid an increase in tax rates because they face less frictions in shifting income to forms that are taxed at a lower rate. Devereux et al. (2014) demonstrate this by analysing income shifting between corporate and personal taxation; Harju and Matikka (2016) for shifting between wages and dividends and Le Maire and Schjerning (2013) for intertemporal shifting. This paper analyses shifting between tax bases by owners of small corporations in the Netherlands using individual tax filings.Footnote 1 Managing directors who own at least 5% of a corporation fall in a specific tax regime. These owners are abbreviated as DGA (Directeur-GrootAandeelhouder in Dutch ).Footnote 2 DGAs face different types of taxation: taxation of corporate income (according to a two-rate structure), progressive taxation of labour income, proportional taxation of dividend income and proportional taxation of personal wealth (above a threshold). As a consequence, they can exploit several opportunities to minimise the tax burden by shifting income between fiscal partners, between labour and dividend income and, in particular, over time. We report three findings, using individual tax records of DGAs and the firms they own for the years 2007–2011. First, DGAs have an incentive to report a low wage income to avoid the progressive taxation of labour income. A reference level is specified and although this is not an absolute legal minimum, many DGAs seem to interpret it in this way. Estimates of the discontinuity show that the density of gross wage income strongly peaks at the reference level for all years. Second, taxable labour income bunches at the cut-offs of the tax brackets, in particular at the top tax cut-off. The elasticity of taxable income ranges from 0.06 to 0.11. This elasticity is defined as the percentage change in taxable income due to a percentage change in one minus the marginal tax rate. In line with Le Maire and Schjerning (2013), we show that bunching at the top tax bracket cut-off is mainly driven by intertemporal income shifting and less by atemporal shifting. The possibility of atemporal tax shifting could be limited by the legal conditions which have to be met in paying out a wage. The conditions determine a certain minimum wage comparable to wage payments of other workers with similar tasks. Third, we analyse the low frequency of dividend payments that are taxed at a flat rate. We exploit the temporary reduction of the tax rate in 2007 to demonstrate the strong responses by DGAs. The 3%-lower rate caused substantial bunching of distributed profits at the upper end of the tax bracket, resulting in a sharp increase in tax revenues. The responses of self-employed and business owners to taxes are estimated in two types of studies. The first type uses the bunching method, initiated by Saez (2010). This approach exploits the prediction that tax payers bunch at kink points of the budget set that arise from discontinuous changes in marginal tax rates. Moreover, he shows that the elasticity of taxable income with respect to the net-of-tax rate is proportional to the amount of bunching. Saez (2010) finds that the bunching around the first threshold of the EITC-schedule in the US can be entirely attributed to recipients with self-employment income. The elasticity of income of self-employed and pure wage earners is estimated around one and zero, respectively. Bunching is not found for the other EITC thresholds. Furthermore, the bunching evidence at the kink points of the federal income tax schedule does not seem different between wage earners and self-employed. 
Chetty et al. (2011) find that taxable income of Danish self-employed bunches at the middle tax bracket cut-off (with an elasticity of 0.24) but in particular at the top tax cut-off (elasticity of 0.1), whereas the distribution is smooth for wage earners. Using the same data, Le Maire and Schjerning (2013) show that more than half (\(50-70\%\)) of the estimated bunching is driven by income shifting, in particular using retained earnings.Footnote 3 When the possibility of income shifting is neglected, the taxable income elasticity is estimated in the range of \(0.43-0.53\). Distinguishing between real responses and income shifting reduces the structural elasticity to the range \(0.14-0.20\). As a consequence, the elasticity is not a sufficient statistic for the deadweight loss when not corrected for income shifting. 
Bastani and Selin (2014) apply the bunching method to kink points in the tax schedule in Sweden. In contrast to wage earners, the density of taxable income of self-employed shows significant excess mass at the first kink point, where the marginal tax rate is increased by a maximum of \(23\%\) points.Footnote 4 However, the implied compensated elasticity of taxable earnings is small (0.024). When the sample is restricted to ‘purely’ self-employed, i.e. those who only report business income from the firm they own, the elasticity increases to 0.027. In addition, bunching also becomes significant at the second kink, where the marginal tax rate increases by \(5\%\) points, with an elasticity of 0.012. Our estimates of the elasticity of taxable labour income are best compared to the outcomes of this type of studies.Footnote 5 Differences in elasticity values can be attributed to, first, institutional differences in the tax code and, second, the change in the marginal tax rate at the kink studied (Chetty et al. 2011). Our estimates, between 0.06 and 0.11, found for an increase in the marginal tax rate of 10% are low when compared to Saez (2010), Chetty et al. (2011) and Le Maire and Schjerning (2013). Saez (2010) finds the largest elasticity (around one) in response to the largest increase in the tax rate (34 and 40% for tax filers with one child and two and more children, respectively). Chetty et al. (2011) report a large elasticity of 0.24 around the top tax cutoff at which the tax rate increases by 30%. However, the elasticity of 0.1 at the middle tax cutoff with an increase of the tax rate of 11% is very similar to our case. Comparing to Le Maire and Schjerning (2013) is more difficult since they report averages over years as well as over two tax brackets. Finally, Bastani and Selin (2014) report the smallest elasticities, notwithstanding a sizable increase in the tax rate (around 20%). Chetty et al. (2011) argue that the elasticity of taxable income is larger for more sizable changes in the marginal tax rate due to adjustment costs. The second type of empirical studies uses panel regressions. Kleven and Schultz (2014) use panel data to estimate effects of changes in tax rates following various reforms in Denmark. They find (in Table 8) that the broad income (this is labour plus capital income, before tax deductions) of the self-employed responds more strongly to the net-of-tax rate on labour income than broad income of wage earners (elasticity of 0.084 versus 0.052). The elasticity to the net-of-tax rate on capital income is significant for wage earners (0.014) but not for the self-employed. Similar results are found for taxable income (i.e. after tax deductions).Footnote 6
 
Harju and Matikka (2016) examine responses by owners of privately held corporations to dividend and wage income taxes in Finland, using panel regressions. In particular, they distinguish between real responses and income shifting between tax bases. They find that the dividend tax base significantly reacts to the dividend tax rate, whereas the wage tax base is not significantly related to its own rate. Moreover, the cross-elasticity of both bases is significant, indicating that income shifting accounts for a large part of the behavioural responses. The marginal excess burden of taxation is substantially lower when the income shifting effect is included in the calculation.Footnote 7
 
Alstadsaeter and Jacob (2016) use a dif-in-dif regression to estimate the effect of a cut in the dividend tax rate by 10 percentage points on income shifting for Sweden. They find that owner-managers of closely held corporations responded by shifting about \(6\%\) of total gross income from labour income to dividends, when compared to the unaffected group of owners of unincorporated businesses. In contrast, their total gross income was not significantly increased. 
Kleven and Schultz (2014) compare the estimated elasticities of both approaches using Danish tax data. They find that the panel-based estimates are larger than the bunching-based estimates. They argue that the panel-based estimates are potentially more revealing of long-run behaviour. We cannot apply panel estimation since we do not have sufficient variation in the tax rates in the short sample. The paper is structured as follows. In the next section we describe the tax system, in particular the taxation of DGAs and the corporations they own. Section 3 presents the two datasets stemming from different types of tax filings. Section 4 discusses the bunching results found for the wage income declared by DGAs around its minimum level. Section 5 reports the results for labour income around the cut-offs of the tax bracket. The taxation of non-labour income of DGAs is studied in Sect. 6. Section 7 concludes.

Title: Income Differences Between PhDs and Masters: Evidence from The Netherlands
U.S. Immigration Reform and the Migration Dynamics of Mexican Males
Intro:
Immigration policies restrict the entrance of persons from other countries. There is a range of these policies from quotas that establish a maximum number of work and residence permits to be issued to foreigners to admission criteria that limit access (Boeri and van Ours 2013). Admission criteria can be based on a point system in which individual-specific characteristics such as education, experience and language abilities are important. Admission criteria can also be based on family relationships or labor market conditions such as shortage of specific skills. During a large part of the twentieth century U.S. immigration was restricted through quota while over the last decades it was largely determined by family considerations, i.e. entry visas were assigned to those who had family members already in the U.S. (Daniels 2002). The annual number of immigrants to the U.S. increased from a quarter of million in the 1950s to nearly half a million in the 1970s and close to a million in the 1990s. In the same time period, there was also big change in the source composition with a sharp rise in immigration from Asia and Mexico. In addition to the sharp rise of legal migration to the U.S. there was a big increase in unauthorized immigration, especially from Mexico (Clark et al. 2007). The Immigration Reform and Control Act (IRCA) of 1986 was the first legislative reform aimed at tackling the growth of unauthorized immigrants. It intended to control and deter illegal immigration to the US through legalization of unauthorized immigrants, increased border security, and sanctions on employers which hired unauthorized immigrants. The law gave a legal status to about 2.7 million unauthorized immigrants in the years following its enactment (Baker 2010). Despite this effort, the number of illegal migrants residing in the US continued to grow and stabilized at about 11 million since 2005 (Baker and Rytina 2013; Passel and Cohn 2016). We evaluate the effects that the IRCA had on the migration dynamics of Mexican males. Changes in immigration law can affect the migrant stock in a country through several channels. A policy change may have an effect through both migrant inflow and outflow which in turn depend on the propensity to migrate to the country, the duration of stay, and the average number of trips each immigrant makes. Our study aims to investigate the overall effect of the IRCA on a Mexican-born individual. We distinguish between the effect on the propensity of taking a first unauthorized trip to the US and the duration of the first stay in the US. In doing so, we attempt to separate the effects of the IRCA on the duration of stay of those migrants who are unauthorized throughout their stay from those who eventually receive legal status, as legalization limits the newly legal migrant’s return behavior.Footnote 1 We compare the results with those of legal immigrants. To measure the overall effect of the reform we use a timing-of-events approach. In particular, we estimate a multivariate migration rate model which aims to detect a change in the age of initial migration and that of a return following the change in law. In our empirical analysis, we use survey data of Mexican households provided by the Mexican migration project (MMP). Since the IRCA is a comprehensive policy change that may have affected all immigrants to the US there is no natural control group. Thus, previous studies on the effect of the IRCA use different identification strategies. Orrenius and Zavodny (2003) and White et al. (1990) use time dummies to measure the effect of the IRCA on apprehension levels to ascertain whether the policy reduced undocumented migration. Donato et al. (1992) also used annual time dummies to analyze the trend of first and repeat migration and apprehension levels after the IRCA. White et al. (1990) find that the IRCA reduced apprehension rates in the first 2 years, further analysis reveals that apprehensions fell in the few months after the law but reverted to the pre-IRCA levels after that (Orrenius and Zavodny 2003). Donato et al. (1992) also agree that the IRCA did not affect the rate of migration to the US and find that it did not change repeat migration patterns either.Footnote 2
 Several studies on migrants in the US differentiate between individuals whose trip initiated before and after the IRCA. The conclusion from these studies is mixed. Reyes (2001) and Li (2016) find that the duration of Mexican migrants trip increased for those who moved after the IRCA, while Quinn (2014) finds no change. However, this analysis does not take into account the effect of the IRCA on the many migrants whose trip started before the policy but lasted long enough to be affected by it. Similar to the work of Donato et al. (1992), we attempt to identify the effect of the IRCA by observing the change over time in a Mexican individual’s conditional probability of migration and return. However, we use an alternative identification strategy by examining the year-by-year change in the conditional probability of migrating and the conditional probability of return migration. As in comparable migration studies, we focus on Mexican males distinguishing various groups of immigrants.Footnote 3 The legal immigrant population of the US consists of two groups of migrants. Legal residents are non-citizens allowed to live and work in the country permanently by a permit termed legal permanent resident (LPR). Naturalized citizens are foreign-born individuals who became citizens of the US. The non-immigrant population or temporary migrants include students, holders of various temporary work permits and their family but does not include short-term visitors for pleasure and business. Lastly, unauthorized migrants, also known as illegal immigrants and illegal residents, are foreign-born individuals who reside in the US but are neither legal immigrants, temporary migrants, nor short-term visitors. In our analysis we focus on unauthorized immigrants from Mexico who entered the US without authorizing documents and legal immigrants who hold LPR permits.Footnote 4 We find that the IRCA was effective in reducing the first-time uptake of an unauthorized trip to the US by young males. The IRCA has not affected their initial duration of stay. In addition, the IRCA did not affect the legal migration rate or the return from a legal trip by Mexican immigrants. Our contribution to the literature on immigration policy is threefold. First, we provide a concise account of unauthorized migrants’ behavior after the introduction of the IRCA. We investigate whether there was indeed a one-time effect and assess the effectiveness of the IRCA in reaching its objectives. Second, we study the effect of the immigration policy on the age of onset of migration and the duration of the first migration spell using hazard rate analysis. Hazard rate analysis has the advantage of allowing for time-varying variables to affect an individual’s behavior over time. It also takes into account that the behavior of an individual may change as the individual gets older or as the trip progresses. Third, we use a rich dataset that covers migrants from 154 communities in 24 out of 32 states in Mexico. The large dataset allows us to measure both migration and return behavior over time in each individual and take into account important factors that affect behavior. Our paper is structured as follows. In the next section, we give a brief overview of the IRCA and the Mexican immigration to the US. Section 3 describes our data from the Mexican migration project. Section 4 sets out the empirical migration rate model based on the age of onset of migration and presents relevant parameter estimates. Section 5 discusses the set-up of the return migration model based on the duration of the first trip and presents related parameter estimates. Section 6 concludes.

Title: Erratum to: Gender Differences in Financial Education: Evidence from Primary School
Impact Assessment of Competition Policies and Regulation: 10 Years’ Experience from the Office of the Chief Economist in the Netherlands
Intro: On April 1 2006, the Office of the Chief Economist was established at the Netherlands Competition Authority (NMa). To celebrate the tenth anniversary in 2016, the Netherlands Authority for Consumers and Markets (ACM, the NMa’s successor) organized a conference on the “Impact assessment of Interventions of Competition and Consumer Authorities”. The conference was attended by scientists, policymakers, practitioners and Chief Economists of different competition authorities and the European Commission. From the very beginning, the NMa’s Chief Economist and his team took the initiative to calculate the possible impact of interventions by the Dutch competition and regulatory authority on the economy. In 2008, a Special Issue of De Economist on the possible measurement of the impact of competition authorities was published.Footnote 1 In this 2008 Special Issue the papers concentrated on the pros and cons of quantifying interventions by competition watchdogs. Some authors were rather sceptical about the calculation methods, while others stressed the political necessity of exposing the impact. In the introduction to that Special Issue (Don et al. 2008), it was stressed that some authorities are required by law to provide some form of impact assessment: “Accountability is particularly requested by politics. For instance in the US, the Government Performance and Result Act of 1993 is one of the reasons why the US Department of Justice (US DoJ) and the Federal Trade Commission (FTC) have been calculating the impact of their enforcement activities ever since 1999... Also in the UK, measurement of the impact of enforcement activities is important as consumer savings is one of the targets to be met by the Office of Fair Trading (OFT). Under the 2007 Comprehensive Spending Review settlement, the OFT agreed to the target that the direct financial benefits to consumers are at least five times that of OFT’s cost to taxpayers”. In the Netherlands, ACM voluntarily publish the impact of its interventions in its annual; report for the first time in 2004. Since that time, several authorities have continued developing the calculation method of the economic impact of their workFootnote 2 and publish about it annually. Another conclusion of the Special Issue of De Economist in 2008, was that more evaluation studies should be conducted. Such ex-post evaluations are important for two main reasons: they constitute an additional method of justifying the oversight of markets, and they teach the authority which interventions are (most) effective. In the last decade, there has been a growing interest in impact analysis by authorities (as pointed out, for example, by the OECD 2014, 2016). A comparison of methodologies for ex-post evaluations in competition policy has been provided by Davies and Ormosi (2012), and an overview of such ex-post studies in competition policy has been presented in Ilzkovitz and Dierx (2015). An overview of studies on the impact of US merger control has been presented in Kwoka (2014). The European Commission is also actively engaging in impact assessment, as shown by two recent studies considering the impact of competition policy on energy markets (European Commission 2016) and on telecom markets (European Commission 2017). Ex-post analyses have become more important especially in relation to merger control. Recently, LEAR (2015) performed a study on the effect of several supermarket mergers in the Netherlands on price, quality and variety of product offerings. In the hospital sector, Kemp et al. (2012) investigated the effect of mergers on the price of hip surgery in the Netherlands and found that prices increased at most merged hospitals, and Broers and Kemp (2017) showed that the quality of care did not improve after the merger. In a randomized field experiment, Huizingh and Mulder (2015) investigated the effectiveness of different ways of providing guidance to e-commerce firms about the legal rules on information disclosure, and showed that letters by post mail slightly increased compliance. Regularly, knowledge and experiences are shared with other regulators and scholars, both domestic and abroad, in order to gain insight into the methods and results of others. This Special Issue gives an overview of such exchange of applied research results on the impact of competition policy. It gives an impression of the state of the art of impact assessment.

Title: ‘Outcome’ Assessment: What Exactly Are We Measuring? A Personal Reflection on Measuring the Outcomes from Competition Agencies’ Interventions
Intro:
How can we determine whether or not a competition agency is doing a good job? There are many reasons why we might want to know. As Kovacic (2009) puts it: “Agency reputations can be likened to brands, and having a well-respected brand is an extremely valuable asset. Current perceptions of agency quality influence legislative decisions about budgets and additions to the agency’s statutory agency, judicial decisions about whether to defer to an agency’s positions, judgments by company officials about whether to comply with mandates subject to the agency’s supervision, the level of morale of existing agency employees, and the agency’s success in recruiting new staff. A broadly held view that an agency is fulfilling its duties capably also contributes to citizen confidence in public governance and thereby strengthens the legitimacy of public administration”. There are also many different measures that can be used to try to find out. My focus here is on the quantified estimates competition agencies publish about the overall direct effect of their actions
Footnote 1 upon the economy, typically reported or updated annually, often for the purposes of including in the annual report. I will call this ‘outcome assessment’ here as this is the term the Netherlands Authority for Consumers and Markets (ACM) uses. Elsewhere, the term ‘impact assessment’ is more common. I will later argue that both are misnomers. However, there are many different ways of assessing competition agency performance and it is essential to distinguish them. The options could be categorised in different ways but might include for example, the following: 
Activity measures simply attempt to quantify how hard the agency is working: the number of cases of different types, perhaps also the number of decisions and remedial actions, the number of fines and so on. Such measures are rightly disparaged for being misleadingFootnote 2 and can lead to perverse incentives if embodied in agency or staff objectives.Footnote 3 However, they are by far the most common assessment measure in use, reported by 100% of the respondents to a survey of evaluation methods.Footnote 4 A decision to reject other approaches to agency evaluation therefore tacitly leaves ‘activity’ as the sole remaining measure. 
Ex-post evaluations typically consider a single concluded case—or a few cases—and seek using subsequent market developments to evaluate how well the agency performed in any aspect of the case. Such studies often focus on whether the decision and analysis performed to reach it, were correct but procedural and administrative matters can be assessed as well (indeed, some of the most influential ex-post studies have been of the effectiveness of remedies, rather than relating to substantive decision-making). A few studies attempt to evaluate case decision-making or other aspects of case handling and analysis on a wider scale, typically using stock market event studies.Footnote 5
 
Surveys of stakeholders provide feedback on various aspects of performance, as well as overall assessments of the ‘quality’ of the institution. The Global Competition Review ratings are the most prominent such survey focused on the agencies themselves, based on soundings among practitioners.Footnote 6 The World Economic Forum’s Global Competitiveness ranking, derived from a survey of business people, includes the question “In your country, how effective are anti-monopoly policies at ensuring fair competition?”.Footnote 7
 Measures of how often the agency wins and loses when its decisions are appealed to courts (or other appellate bodies) are an obvious way of assessing quality and one that senior competition officials themselves understandably find compelling.Footnote 8 A competition agency that loses most of its appeals is doing something wrong and a poor record will usually cause an agency to rethink its approach. That said, a perfect record might indicate an over-cautious agency (or one with a light standard of review) rather than perfect judgement. 
Outcome measures: assessment of the total benefits provided by the competition agency’s actions over a year—the topic of this paper. Even this list covers only approaches which purport to measure agency performance. The wider field of evaluation of competition policy includes assessment of the strengths and weaknesses of the legal and institutional frameworks in place,Footnote 9 as well as studies of the effects of differences in laws and institutions, over time or between jurisdictions.Footnote 10
 The different approaches above each have their strengths and weaknesses. Fairly obviously, activity measures say nothing about the quality of a competition agency’s decisions: a very active agency could be taking a lot of bad decisions. At the other extreme, a detailed ex-post assessment of a specific case could evaluate the quality of an agency’s work on that case in detail but the case might not be typical of the agency’s activities. The different approaches provide complementary perspectives. For one thing, there are many different reasons for assessing performance. Don et al. (2008) identify three: accountability to supervising institutions, undertaking quality control of decisions and reviewing the effectiveness of competition law. To these, I would add a fourth: monitoring for internal management control.Footnote 11
 My focus here is on outcome assessment, which is held to be useful primarily for accountability in this framework, although I would widen the scope of accountability beyond ‘supervising institutions’ (such as government, and especially finance ministries) in the spirit of the quote from Kovacic (2009) at the start of this paper. Outcome assessment is also sometimes seen as a measure of the effectiveness of competition law and a tool for internal control, especially to guide agency case selection towards those cases with the largest likely impact. I will define outcome assessment to involve a competition agency (or an agent acting on its behalf): Quantifying and summing the outcome (or impact, or value) of all, or almost all of its interventions over a period such as a year. Doing so using primarily information available at the time the decision was taken, rather than evidence on how the intervention has affected things in the marketplace. Such quantification is therefore an estimate. It is particularly important to distinguish outcome measurement (number six in the list above) from the ex post review of case decisions on the basis of subsequent market developments (number two). As outcome assessment is based on estimates, it is very different indeed from such ex post reviews. However, these two assessment approaches are very frequently discussed together. They will often be undertaken by the same units within a competition agency, they are jointly taken as the subject of conferences and the publications that emerge from them (including this one). Because of this, they are sometimes discussed as if they are alternatives, with economists especially preferring the greater precision and factual basis of a well-conducted ex post case assessment. To my mind, arguing about whether one is better or more useful than the other is rather a waste of time. They are completely different activities, aimed at different purposes, using different methodologies and producing entirely different results. Good ex post assessment can yield extremely valuable estimates of the effects of specific competition agency interventions. In such studies, careful collection of factual data and use of econometric techniques to assess the counterfactual can produce accurate quantitative estimates of direct impact and even some clues about longer-term effects. Enough of these studies have now been done for conclusions to be drawn from meta-studies across them to enrich the policy debate.Footnote 12
 Ex post assessment is essential for agency performance improvement but of limited use for the purpose of accountability.Footnote 13 Government and other stakeholders might not be satisfied by hearing examples of specific case outcomes. Furthermore, if an agency relies upon the results of ex post studies to make its case to such stakeholders, there is a danger of cases being selected for review if the results are expected to be favourable, when there is more to be learnt from cases that the agency might have got wrong. A broader evaluation is needed to complement such snapshots. The question I address here is not whether ‘outcome assessment’ is better or worse than other things a competition agency could do; simply whether it is worth doing at all. My answer is a qualified yes, but that ‘outcome assessment’ should be seen as a way of producing a more sophisticated measure of activity, rather than as a measure of outcomes.

Title: Economic Impact of Competition Policy: A Look Beyond Consumer Surplus
Intro: In the static setting, the execution of competition policy has relatively clear implications on prices and consequently the size of the consumer and producer surplus. The aim of competition policies is a general welfare enhancement assumed to be achieved through increased market efficiency but the focus of competition authorities tends to be directed mainly towards the short term impact on consumers. Van Sinderen and Kemp (2008) elaborate on the motivation for the tendencies. Nevertheless, although the policies are likely to increase welfare by reducing the deadweight loss critics might object that firms boast more powerful tools serving as a multiplier of their profits compared to consumers and hence, they may stimulate production growth by means of increased investments (e.g. in R&D). Moreover, the size of the welfare loss due to the presence of market power referred to as the Harberger triangle is often estimated to be rather small. To mention the examples for relatively low and large estimates, Schwartzman (1960) and Scherer and Ross (1990) come up with estimates of 0.01 and 1.3% of GDP, respectively. Nevertheless, broader effects of increased competition on the economy should be taken into account. For instance, Browning (1997) notes that output mix distortion is not the only outcome of market power as also factor prices are affected. Furthermore, Matheron (2002) argues that the dynamics of the effects should also be taken into account. Another strand of literature finds that increased competition is likely to enhance innovation, productivity and consequently, economic growth (Brouwer and van der Wiel 2010; Aghion et al. 2005). This literature, however, also notes that the returns to increased competition are diminishing and after reaching an optimum they turn negative. As a consequence of the above considerations, study of dynamic effects of interventions in the market may yield conclusions substantially different than those from a static analysis. Moreover, also non-allocative inefficiencies other than technological are likely to be affected by competition law enforcement (Leibenstein 1966). Finally, other market distortions such as taxes magnify the negative effects of imperfect competition as shown e.g. by Browning (1997) or Jonsson (2007). This is crucial to consider as distortionary taxation is present in virtually all economies. Macroeconomic simulations allow us to take into account a broad range of effects including those that may be negative. In the MESEMET-2 model the distortions of taxation on the economy are modelled (see Van Sinderen 1993; Van Bergeijk et al. 1995, 1997). Also the impact on technological progress and infrastructure is included. The full original MESEMET-2 model can be found in Donselaar and van Sinderen (2000). Applications of the model can be found in Van Sinderen (1993), Van Sinderen and Kemp (2008), Van Bergeijk et al. (1995, 1997), Donselaar et al. (2003) or Van Hagen (1995). In this paper we will explicitly model the effect of competition on non-allocative efficiency and the relationship between competition and R&D. Thereby, we look at the ultimate outcome of the positive impact of increased competition on R&D and efficiency and the negative impact on investments due to the cut in the producer surplus. In the simulation by Van Sinderen and Kemp (2008) a cut in prices as a result of an intervention by a competition authority is thought to have a comparable impact on an economy as a cut in labour taxes. This approach is based on the economic literature on imperfect competition that states that anti-competitive behaviour creates wedges between prices and marginal costs, in the same way as taxes do. ...the effects of monopolistic competition are simular to those deriving from a constant tax on income associated with lump sum transfers... (Matheron (2002), p. 132) Using a cut in taxes as a proxy to estimate the effects of interventions by an authority to fight anti-competitive behaviour has its disadvantages. First of all a cut in taxation has an impact on the budget deficit which is not the case with anti-competitive interventions. Second, a cut in wage tax directly affects labor demand and supply unlike actions of a competition authority. Third, the redistribution of the producer surplus to the consumer as a result of the intervention by the competition authority has an impact on companies and their investment behaviour. In general such a redistribution will increase consumption and decrease investments in the short term. The impact in the longer term depends on the elasticities in the economy and will be investigated in this paper. In the present analysis, we use a version of the model with a recent calibration and model the decrease of market power in a more direct manner by introducing modifications to the original model instead of using a tax cut as a proxy. We introduce non-allocative efficiencies, mark-ups and effects on R&D, and therefore, we verify whether positive overall effects are attained also through alternative routes, which more closely correspond to dynamics expected to be caused by changes in market power. The paper is further structured as follows: Sect. 2 explains the motivation for conducting macroeconomic simulations, Sect. 3 presents the model MESEMET-2, Sect. 4 discusses the approach used to model the effects, Sect. 5 presents the results from the simulations and Sect. 6 concludes.

Title: The Impact of Regulation on Utilities’ Investments: A Survey and New Evidence from the Energy Industry
Intro: One primary goal of regulation is to promote market efficiency and to improve social welfare (Armstrong and Sappington 2006). However, to achieve this goal a conflict between social and private interests may arise between pro-competitive and efficiency enhancing regulatory regimes and the firm’s incentives to invest. In the words of Laffont and Tirole (2000), “there is in general a trade-off between promoting competition to increase social welfare once the infrastructure is in place and encouraging ex ante the incumbent to invest and maintain the infrastructure”. This tension is typical of all regulated firms, and particularly so of energy utilities, and explains why the relationship between regulation and investments has driven a lot of attention by economic theory. In turn, investments affect welfare along different dimensions (Guthrie 2006). First, investments ultimately affect both prices and quantities in the long run, and delayed investment can adversely impact industry performance and in turn economic growth. Second, investments of regulated infrastructure sectors often entail a huge financial effort and a substantial risk. To achieve the goal of an effective regulation, during the past half century, regulatory frameworks all around the world have undergone a substantial transformation in the institutional configuration, instruments and goals. In this paper, we analyse such evolution and assess its impact on the utilities’ investments drawing from recent academic analysis in the last few decades. The institutional setting of the regulatory environment was redefined starting from mid Eighties. Before then, network utilities were almost without exception under direct public control. At that time, a wave of liberalizations hit the whole network utilities sector in the attempt to increase firms’ efficiency and curb incumbents’ market power. The process of liberalization includes a number of measures aimed at reducing the barriers, restrictions and rigidities that inhibit the free operation of the market. The milestone legislation introducing market liberalization is the European Commission Directive 96/92 for the electricity, followed by EC Directive 98/30 for the gas market. The purpose of these directives was to introduce competition in generation and distribution, as well as to vertically separate the different segments in the energy value chain. Liberalization was occasionally associated to the privatization of the former State-owned firms. The newly established companies were de facto monopolies operating in a liberalized market, and required a greater regulatory commitment than what a ministry or an executive-branch commission could ever lend. In fact, in the absence of a credible ability to commit by regulators, a severe time-inconsistency issue would arise. Such inconsistency would critically undermine the utilities’ incentives to invest, especially when investments are irreversible. As a consequence, and in parallel with the liberalization reforms, independent regulatory agencies were established in many countries. The aim was twofold: first, the regulation of the newly privatized utilities; second, insulating the regulatory action from political interference. Under this respect, the economic literature shows that the presence of a stand-alone regulatory body has significantly increased the firms’ investments, as discussed in the next section. Some ten years later new instruments were gradually introduced to carry out the regulatory action. Traditional rate of return regulation, which essentially reimbursed utilities for the costs incurred in the production, was typically found wanting in regards of productive efficiency, on the grounds of reduced incentives to raise it due to managerial slack. As a consequence, cost-based mechanisms were gradually substituted by incentive regulation schemes, such as price- or revenue-cap, or profit- or revenue-sharing. The adoption of such schemes leaves the firms with allowed revenues that do not depend on realized cost savings. If the regulated firm is able to increase its efficiency and reduce costs further than the regulator anticipates through the X-factor, its profit will go up. If it is less efficient than expected, its profit will go down. Thus, the regulated firm is expected to have higher incentives to invest in cost reducing activities to improve efficiency, “beat the X-factor” (Littlechild 1983) and in turn increase its profits.Footnote 1 On the other hand, rate of return regulation performs differently than price cap regulation with respect to investments in infrastructure. In fact, under rate of return regulation, the rate of return on the asset base is guaranteed, thus considerably reducing the risk faced by the firm. Therefore, firms under RoR have stronger incentives to expand their infrastructure, when the allowed cost of capital is larger than the market return. Such incentives are weakened under price cap mechanisms, especially when the regulatory lags are shorter than the life of the assets, due to regulatory opportunism, as empirically found by Lyon and Mayo (2005). The empirical literature on the subject shows that incentive-base mechanisms perform better than rate of return to induce productive efficiency.Footnote 2 Moreover, incentives (specifically in the form of the X-factorFootnote 3) appear to be the most significant driver of investments aimed at increase firm efficiency. While these results hold true when incentive regulation was first introduced, the evolution of the policymakers’ goals in the last few years brought a change in the impact of incentive regulation as well, by introducing more hybrid incentive mechanism comprising elements of both pure incentive and cost-of–service schemes. To test whether the evolution of regulators’ goals actually translated onto the instruments used in the regulatory practice, this paper examines the regulation implemented in a panel of European energy utilities from 1997 to 2013. Unfortunately, the unavailability of micro data that distinguish between different types of investments (for example, replacement, quality improvements, innovation or network extension) does not allow us to infer welfare implications. Nevertheless, our analysis finds that firms under incentive or other hybrid forms of regulation invest more than firms under traditional cost-plus mechanisms, a result perhaps informative for the policy-maker that this data may obtain. Moreover, our results show that investments increase with the allowed rate of return, but they are not affected significantly by the X-factor. A possible interpretation is that after a long period of implementation of efficiency-oriented mechanisms, regulation has become less stringent in recent years and rather more focused on stimulating investments in quality, security of supply or in infrastructure expansion and innovation. Indeed, in the last few years, the goal of the regulatory action widened to address the ever increasing quality concerns of policy makers. The traditional efficiency objectives have thus been flanked by output-based targets such as energy efficiency, reliability and innovation. A precursor along this course has been the UK Revenue, Incentives, Innovation and Output (RIIO) model, adopted by Ofgem (2010). Nowadays virtually all regulatory systems have adopted some form of output regulation, with the introduction of quality and innovation incentives into the regulatory mechanisms. The empirical evidence finds that setting quality targets was indeed a spur to investments, although incentives appear to have an asymmetric impact, with penalties having higher effectiveness than rewards. The paper is organized as follows. In Sect. 2 we study the impact of independent regulation, paying particular attention to the effect of the institutional environment upon the establishment and effectiveness of regulatory agencies that are endowed with de facto independence. In Sect. 3 we analyse the impact of regulatory mechanisms, by comparing the effects of rate of return and incentive regulation on investments. Section 4 explores the recent developments of incentive regulation by studying its effects on a panel of European energy utilities throughout the period 1997–2013. Section 5 we address the recent available literature on quality regulation and Sect. 6 concludes.

Title: Ex-post Analysis of Mobile Telecom Mergers: The Case of Austria and The Netherlands
Intro:
Companies use mergers to combine forces in order to expand markets, develop new products more efficiently or reduce production or distribution costs. However, some mergers may reduce competition as well which may harm consumers through higher prices, reduced choice or less innovation and quality. The objective of merger control is to ensure that notified mergers are only cleared if they are not expected to entail significant anticompetitive effects on parameters like price, quality, innovation and variety. While the merger control is usually based upon expectations and hypotheses, ex-post evaluation can shed light on the actual procompetitive or anticompetitive effects of consummated mergers. Recently, increased attention is being paid to ex-post evaluation of competition policy enforcement decisions, and in particular merger decisions. In the United States, there is already an established and voluminous body of studies that covers several industries and several types of decisions (Kwoka 2013). In this paper, we empirically examine the effects on retail prices of two mergers in the mobile telecommunication industry: T-Mobile-tele.ring merger in Austria, approved with remediesFootnote 1 in April 2006.Footnote 2
 T-Mobile-Orange merger in the Netherlands, approved without remedies in August 2007.Footnote 3
 This paper hence contributes to a limited, but growing, number of ex-post assessments in Europe (Mariuzzo et al. 2016) and aims at improving our understanding of consummated mergers. The mobile telecom industry is an industry of significant interest for merger control, as the European mobile telecom sector has witnessed several recent mergers between independent mobile network operators in a number of different national markets. Mergers in that industry also tend to have long-lasting effects due to very high entry barriers because of the need to acquire very costly spectrum and to roll out a mobile network. The mobile telecom industry also presents a number of interesting specificities (complex tariff offers, non-linear prices) that this study tries to address and that might also be relevant to other industries. Mainly due to issues of data availability, this study is limited to the effects of the mentioned mergers on retail prices. We are aware, however, that a merger may also affect other market outcomes such as investments and quality.Footnote 4
 Insights of retrospective merger evaluations can contribute to improving the enforcement practice of competition authorities in various ways. Retrospective merger analysis allows testing the merits of arguments commonly brought forward in past cases. Ex-post evaluation can also help competition authorities to calibrate the merger policy by identifying potential systematic biases in merger decisions. For example, in a recent survey, Kwoka (2013) finds that mergers which are conditionally cleared in the US often still had significant anti-competitive effects. This study applies reduced-form econometric methods typically used in the so-called treatment evaluation literature, which are commonly applied also to the ex-post assessment of competition policy. Effectively, we compare, both before and after the merger, the price development of the country in which the respective analysed merger took place (“affected country”) with a number of countries in which no structural change took place over the same period (“control countries”). This permits to estimate the price development that would have been observed in the country of interest absent the merger and to identify the merger effect. Specifically, we apply a difference-in-differences (DiD) approach which is widely used in the policy evaluation literature and for ex-post evaluation of mergers. We also test whether our identifying assumption of “common trends” in the studied countries is met pre-merger. As in many case studies, we observe only a single affected country, and overall we have a small sample (in statistical terms) of control countries. We address this challenge by applying recent approaches to improve the estimation of standard errors. The remainder of the paper is organized as follows. In the next section, we give a short introduction of the context of this study, merger control, the mobile telecommunication sector and the selected cases. Section 3 describes the data and the empirical approach. Section 4 presents the results. Section 5 concludes.

Title: Ex-Post Evaluation of Competition Law Enforcement Effects in the German Packaging Waste Compliance Scheme Market
Intro: In recent years the ex-post evaluation of antitrust decisions has increasingly attracted the attention of academia, competition authorities and international organizations. The OECD, for instance, has declared the evaluation of competition interventions as one of the strategic priorities for the OECD’s work on competition between 2012 and 2016. In that context, the OECD has collected information on existing best practices in such evaluations and tried to expand the range of techniques that can be used.Footnote 1 Furthermore, recent events such as the ex-post evaluation workshops organized by the OECD or the conference dedicated to impact assessment organized by the Netherlands Authority for Consumers and Markets have created a platform to discuss ex-post evaluation studies as well as general methodological issues when conducting those studies. There is a common understanding that ex-post evaluations are valuable.Footnote 2 Ex-post studies contribute to an increase in the transparency of decisions and allow to uncover potential welfare benefits generated for consumers as a consequence of enforcement activities. Furthermore, conducting ex-post evaluations allows for an objective assessment of the impact of specific antitrust decisions on market outcomes. The results may be used for improving the quality of antitrust decisions as well as the general enforcement practice in the mid- and long-term. In addition, potential limits of existing rules and regulations may be identified and promote discussions on the necessity of policy reforms. Against this background, we provide an ex-post evaluation of the impact of competition law enforcement activities of the Bundeskartellamt and the European Commission on the German packaging waste compliance scheme market. Until 2003, the non-profit compliance scheme DSD enjoyed a monopoly in the market. Numerous antitrust cases, however, paved the way for competitive market structures. We show that these enforcement activities resulted in a series of market entries since 2004, a corresponding drop in DSD’s market share, increased innovation and substantial efficiencies. Furthermore, we apply a difference-in-differences approach to show that prices decreased by 63% and to estimate the aggregated consumer welfare gains achieved by 2011 at a total of €13 billion. The article is structured as follows. Section 2 briefly summarizes how the German market for packaging waste compliance schemes functions today. Section 3 continues with a description of the creation of DSD as a monopolist, a discussion of the competition issues connected with its monopolistic position and a review of antitrust enforcement activities to enable market entry. Chapter 4 then provides the ex-post evaluation of enforcement activities. After a brief description of the underlying data in Sect. 4.1 we present in Sect. 4.2 several figures to show the impact of competition on the market structure, followed by a difference-in-differences estimation of consumer welfare effects in Sect. 4.3. Section 5 closes the paper with a discussion of the results and policy conclusions.

Title: Sanctions and Leniency to Individuals, and its Impact on Cartel Discoveries: Evidence from the Netherlands
Intro: Agreements between firms about, e.g., prices has a history that goes back for many centuries. Such cartel agreements are illegal in most countries nowadays. One of the reasons of cartel prohibition is that they might result in substantial financial damages to the public: the median overcharge is estimated to be 28% (see e.g. Connor and Bolotova 2006; Connor 2007). Furthermore, effective market competition is deemed fundamental as it encourages firms to become economically efficient. One of the main tasks of a Competition Authority (hence CA) is to fight cartels. On many occasions cartel investigations result in high fines for the firms involved as, e.g., the TV and computer monitor tubes cartel (total fines of €1.47 billion, see, European Commission 2012) in the EU, and the cold-storage cartels in the Netherlands (total fines of €12.5 million, see Authority for Consumers and Markets 2016) show. Yet, many firms still engage in cartels. An important instrument of CAs to fight cartels is the leniency programme. Under such a programme, firms may receive a fine reduction if they provide evidence of their cartel to the CA. The US Department of Justice (hence US DoJ) introduced a leniency programme in 1978 and revised it in 1993 (US Department of Justice 1993). Currently, the first firm to apply for leniency receives a substantial fine reduction, and even automatic immunity from fines if it applies before an investigation has started. The European Union introduced their leniency programme in 1996 and revised it in 2002 (European Commission 1996, 2002). In contrast to the American programme, not only the first firm but any subsequent firms which apply for leniency may also receive a fine reduction. In the Netherlands cartels are illegal since 1998 (NMa 1998). A leniency programme was introduced shortly after in 2002 and was revised in 2007 (Staatscourant 2002; NMa 2007). The programme is similar to the EU leniency programme. One important difference since the revision of the Dutch leniency programme is that also natural persons may be imposed a fine on or may receive leniency.Footnote 1 In this paper we investigate the effect of introducing sanctions and leniency to individuals on cartel discoveries. Several scholars argue that leniency programmes have been successful as many cartels were convicted after a leniency application (see e.g. Motta 2004; Spagnolo 2008). Hammond (2000) already claimed that the leniency programme resulted in most cartel prosecutions of the US DoJ, and recently also commissioner Margrethe Vestager claimed this to be the case in the EU (European Commission 2017). On the other hand, there is a growing literature showing that leniency programmes might also result in more stable cartels (see, a.o., Motta and Polo 2003; Spagnolo 2004; Chen and Harrington 2007). Hence, the success of leniency programmes may be due to more cartels, which would contrast the intention of the programme. Literature on leniency for individuals is limited. Aubert et al. (2006) extend in a theoretical model the leniency programme to individuals, if individuals can be convicted for cartel behaviour. They show that a programme offering positive rewards to individuals for cartel reporting, can be more effective than a corporate leniency programme that grants up to full fine immunity for firms. Moreover, Aubert et al. (2006) argue that implementing individual leniency in a corporate leniency programme is also more effective than corporate leniency alone. Also Bruneckienė and Pekarskienė (2015) argue that the ideal sanction system should include both monetary and non-monetary sanctions (e.g. imprisonment). In the US individuals may be sentenced to imprisonment, but this is not the case in the EU nor in the Netherlands. Furthermore, the ideal sanction system should focus on both firms and individuals. If individuals face possible sanctions, the leniency programme should be extended to individuals as well, as is practice in the Netherlands. The effect of leniency programmes has mostly been examined from a theoretical perspective. Assessing this in an empirical way is more challenging, as there is no information on undetected cartels. A few studies have tested the impact of leniency programmes on cartel formation in an experimental way, but results differ (see e.g. Hinloopen and Soetevent 2008; Bigoni et al. 2012). Some scholars base their conclusions on empirical data. E.g., Miller (2009) shows that the revision of the US leniency programme resulted in more cartel deterrence and detection. In the EU the implementation of the leniency programme did not yield any effect on the size of the cartel population, but cartel investigation duration did decrease (Brenner 2009). Following the line of the empirical work of Miller (2009), we investigate the effect of introducing individual sanctions and leniency in the Netherlands on cartel discoveries.Footnote 2 Our contribution is threefold. First, we investigate the effect of expanding leniency to individuals. Second, we also examine whether a leniency revision leads to more cartel cases with a leniency application. Other empirical papers considered the effect of a revision of the leniency programme on cartel discoveries, without evaluating whether there was an effect on leniency. Third, we expand the panel of countries whose leniency programmes are evaluated, as we are the first to consider the Dutch leniency programme. Our results show that the revision of the leniency programme, by including sanctions for individuals, did not lead to increased detection of cartels: the number of cartel discoveries actually decreases after the revision. We then turn to an analysis of characteristics of all members of the discovered cartels. The analysis indicates that the revision of the Dutch leniency programme lead to enhanced cartel deterrence. Considering only the number of cartel discoveries that included leniency, there is actually a significant drop in the number of cartel cases with leniency after the revision. This implies that it became less attractive to apply for leniency since the revision. The remainder of this paper is organised as follows. Section 2 reviews the relevant literature. The history of the Dutch leniency programme is described in Sect. 3 and we develop our hypotheses in Sect. 4. The data of all Dutch cartels is discussed in Sect. 5. Section 6 discusses the empirical framework, and Sect. 7 discusses the results of our analyses. Section 8 concludes.

Title: Cheaper and More Haircuts After VAT Cut? Evidence from the Netherlands
Impact of Funding Targeted Pre-school Interventions on School Readiness: Evidence from the Netherlands
Fragmentation and Market Quality: The Case of European Markets
Intro: A market is fragmented when the same security trades on multiple trading venues. Fragmentation fosters competition via low-cost and tailored services to different traders, but may harm market quality if quotes and orders are not given the opportunity to interact. The Markets in Financial Instrument Directive (MiFID) that became applicable in late 2007 eliminated the concentration rule that ascribed a quasi-monopoly regime to domestic primary exchanges in the European Union, and encouraged competition between trading venues. Under the concentration rule present in many European countries, competition was constrained by all equity retail orders having to be executed in a regulated market. Following MiFID application, Europe witnessed the proliferation of alternative trading platforms, particularly Multilateral Trading Facilities (MTF), crossing engines, and systematic internalizers.Footnote 1 The number of MTF operating in Europe and their trading activity boomed in the last decade. Conversely, incumbent exchanges faced a significant reduction in market share, partially because of the ability of some very successful MTF to capture trading activity. The rise of MTF like BATS Chi-X Europe corroborates the idea that traditional stock exchanges featured a reduction of market power. This operator became the largest trading platform for equity trading in Europe in 2013. This study addresses the impact of fragmentation/competition on European stock markets following MiFID implementation. In a preliminary analysis, the drivers of MTF trade inception for a large sample of stocks traded in the Eurozone are analyzed. On the grounds that these platforms are ultimately driven by profit motivations, we posit that firm characteristics, such as size and trading activity, help determine MTF trade initiation given their association to potential MTF revenues. Not surprisingly, the findings of this study show that bigger stocks with higher trading activity and liquidity initiated MTF trades earlier than other stocks. Next, the impact of fragmentation/competition on market quality, and more specifically on liquidity, volatility, trading activity, and price informativeness is debated. The effect of MTF trade initiation on market quality is investigated using a sample of 3978 Eurozone stocks, of which 1551 initiated MTF transactions during the period comprised between 2007 and 2015. We analyze changes in a set of market quality variables capturing liquidity, volatility, trading activity, price informativeness, and precision, by means of a difference-in-differences approach and event study methodology. The patterns of market quality before and after the first MTF transaction of each stock and between stocks that did and did not register MTF trades during the analyzed time frame is compared. The analysis is conducted through the lens of two alternative approaches: matching techniques and panel data regression. The first approach employs propensity score matching (and nearest-neighbor matching in non-tabulated robustness tests). The patterns of market quality of “treated” stocks and matched stocks are compared one, three and six-month after the first trade in MTF (event date). Accordingly, the matching approach enables ascertaining short-term impacts of the event. Interestingly, stocks that initiated MTF transactions benefited, in the short-term, from a liquidity increment in the primary exchange (lower transaction costs and price impact of trades) and higher trading activity following that event. Most notably, MTF trade initiation boosted overall visible and consolidated trading activity without reducing the trading activity of incumbent exchanges.
